title: 110_hr1376
content: The "Medicaid Foster Care Coverage Act of 2007" establishes independent foster care adolescents as a mandatory category for Medicaid coverage. The "Medicaid Foster Care Coverage Act of 2007" adds independent foster care adolescents as a mandatory category for Medicaid coverage. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act to include this new category. The Social Security Act is amended to include independent foster care adolescents as a mandatory category for Medicaid coverage. Subclauses are renumbered and sections are revised accordingly. The Social Security Act is amended to include independent foster care adolescents as a mandatory category for Medicaid coverage. Subclauses are renumbered and sections are revised accordingly, including changes to subsections (a)(10) and (cc)(2)(A)(I) of the Act. Section 1903(f)(4) is also amended to update references within the Act. The Social Security Act is amended to include independent foster care adolescents as a mandatory category for Medicaid coverage. Sections of the Act are revised, including changes to subsections (a)(10) and (cc)(2)(A)(I). Section 1916(I) and 1916A(b)(3) of the Social Security Act are amended to replace "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XIX)" with "1902(a)(10)(A)(ii)(XVIII)" in multiple places. Section 1937(a)(2)(B)(x) is also amended accordingly. Effective date provisions are included. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) shall apply to calendar quarters starting on or after October 1, 2007, regardless of final regulations. Exceptions apply if state legislation is required for a State plan under title XIX of the Social Security Act. State legislation is required for the State plan to meet additional requirements imposed by recent amendments. Failure to meet this requirement before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the State legislature's session will not deem the plan non-compliant with the title. In the case of a State with a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature.
